requires large value of retarding potential to stop the electron . if m is the mass and e is the charge of the electron emitted with velocity v and v is the stopping potential then ev Â½ mv2 . thus einstein explained photoelectric effect successfully on the basis of particle nature of light and got nobel prize in 1921 . 1.4compton effect in the year 1916 einstein extended his photon concept and proposed that when light interacts with matter not only energy but also linear momentum of photon get transferred in discrete amount and both law of conservation of energy and law of conservation of momentum hold good . the magnitude of momentum transferred with each photon of frequency f is given by p hfc h  ...  1.12 in 1923 arthur compton at washington university carried out an experiment that gave support to the view of einstein . compton arranged for a beam of xrays of wavelength to fall on a target made of graphite and measured the wavelength and intensity of xrays scattered in various direction from the target . the observed phenomenon is called a compton effect . he received nobel prize in 1927 . 12textbook of engineering physic 1.4.1definition when xrays of sharply defined frequency are incident on a material of low atomic number like carbon they suffer a change of frequency on scattering . the scattered beam contains two wavelength . in addition to the expected incident wavelength there exists a component of longer wavelength . this phenomenon is calledcompton effect . the change in wavelength from incident wavelength to scattered xray wavelength is called compton shift . explanation the classical electromagnetic theory failed to explain compton shift but compton successfully used quantum theory of radiation to explain the phenomenon . accordingly the whole process is treated a a particle collision event between xray photon and a loosely bound electron of the scatterer . in this process both momentum and energy are conserved . in this photonelectron collision a portion of the energy of the photon is transferred to the electron . a a result the xray proceeds with less than the original energy and therefore gain lower frequency or higher wavelength . 1.4.2expression for compton shift the incident photon with an energy h fand momentum h fc strike an electron at rest . the initial momentum of the electron is zero and it initial energy is only the rest mass energy m0c2 . the scattered photon of energy h f and momentum h fc move away in a direction inclined at an angle to the original direction a shown in fig . 1.7. after radiation . in practice a small opening in any heated cavity such a a port in an oven behaves like a blackbody because such an opening trap all incident radiation fig . 1.1. the opening to the cavity inside a body is a good approximation of a blackbody . light entering the small opening strike the far wall where some of it is absorbed but some is reflected at a random angle . the light continues to be reflected and at each reflection a portion of the light is absorbed by the cavity wall . after many reflection essentially all of the incident energy is absorbed . if the direction of the radiation is reversed in fig . 1.1 the light emitted by a small opening is in thermal equilibrium with the wall because it ha been absorbed and reemitted many time . figure 1.1 the opening to the spectrum . 1.3photoelectric effect 1.3.1definition the phenomenon of emission of electron from a metal surface when illuminated by light of suitable frequency is called the photoelectric effect . photoelectric effect wa discovered by h. hertz in 1887 . 8textbook of engineering physic the photoelectric effect involves conversion of light energy into electrical energy . the electron emitted during photoelectric effect are called photoelectron and the current constituted by photoelectron is called the photoelectric current . the minimum frequency of the incident radiation required for the emission of electron from the surface of a metal is called the threshold frequency of the metal . threshold frequency varies from metal to metal . it ha been observed that metal like zinc cadmium magnesium etc . show photoelectric effect only for ultraviolet light . but some alkali metal like lithium sodium potassium caesium and rubidium show photoelectric effect even for visible light . inside the tube fig . 1.4. the tube contains a side window of quartz which allows light of reasonably short wavelength to pas through and allows to fall on cathodec . the electron emitted from cathode c will move towards the anode a. this will constitutes the photoelectron and cause photoelectric current to flow in the circuit and measured using a micro ammeter connected in the circuit . the photoelectric current can be increased or decreased by varying the magnitude and sign of the anode potential with respect to the cathode . it is observed that there is a certain minimum negative retarding potential at anode which will reduce the photoelectric current to be zero and is referred a stopping potential or retarding potential or cutoff potential represented a vs. therefore the stopping potential is defined a the minimum negative potential required at the anode so a to completely suppress the photoelectron reaching the anode and hence the current to zero in the circuit .
